file_content.text: See you around, Lieutenant.
Sir, I was only following the lieutenant's orders. Cooperating with our allies, isn't that the drill?
Captain, you have converted our prison into a... a hotel for enemy nobles!
I already told you, the lieutenant had to rescue the ladies to get Markus to start talking. That's all this is, sir.
The mission was a complete success.
I'm back.
Is this guy giving you trouble, Cormac?
What's going on here?
Lieutenant, sir! You're back! You're just in time.
Ah, the lieutenant, no doubt returning from yet another daring and influential operation on my family's behalf and without our knowledge.
I don't think anyone invited your lordship to come and talk to my prisoners.
Back off, Pallos.
Your prisoners? Yours? Unbelievable. Simply unbelievable.
Would you be so kind as to explain to me why there are three Thul nobles here, insisting that they have a bargain with you?
That information is classified, sir.
I'm afraid I can't.
Enough. You are taking advantage of our house's hospitality to engage in secretive dealings that may or may not even be to our benefit.
I made a deal with Markus to get the information I needed.
Because we do have a bargain.
How dare you make arrangements with House Organa's prisoners without our permission? Indeed, without our very knowledge!
I don't suppose you'd care to share the details of this illicit arrangement that you've conceived, Lieutenant?
I don't know who you think you're talking to, Pallos, but you aren't the boss of me.
Watch your tone.
How dare you? Your attitude is inappropriate--inexcusable!
I will have the truth. What bargain have you struck with this man and his family?
This man and his family have cooperated in full with Republic forces. They are free to go.
I've pardoned Markus.
This is an outrage! You promised amnesty for the very man who tried to murder our honored duke?
This was not your decision to make. You have overstepped your meaningless authority for the last time.
This concession was a mission necessity.
I'm sorry, this had to happen.
And what of your allies in House Organa? Our demands are of no consequence to you?
If you aren't happy, take it up with General Garza.
Talk to my CO.
Why, that's a splendid suggestion! Thank you ever so much.
Guess we won't be friends after all.
Too bad. [Hit Pallos.]
Ungh... how... how dare you strike me? You'll pay for this outrage, Lieutenant--pay dearly!
Your Commanding Officer will hear of what you've done. Good day to you all.
Lieutenant, I... I am surprised. You have risked everything for the sake of my family. Thank you.
Destroying families isn't in my op orders.
You're welcome.
I will forever be in your debt. And Markus Thul never forgets his debts.
Hey, don't take it personally.
I think you've done far more than your job here today.
I can always change my mind, Markus.
Don't make me regret it.
You'll have no reason to do so. I swear it.
Well, sir, I guess that about wraps things up for you here. Let me just say that it's been a real honor working with you, Lieutenant--a real honor.
I couldn't have done it without you, Cormac.
The honor was mine.
Ah, it was nothing, really. Glad I could help.
It's been fun.
It's going to feel great to get off this messed up world.
I can't wait to leave.
Hope we meet again, sir. Good luck out there.
My deal was for the wife and daughter--not Markus.
Markus is still yours.
But... but Markus! My Markus--no, no!
Please! Not father--not father!
Hush now, dears. I knew that this might come to pass. And it is a small price to pay for your safety.
This... this agreement is satisfactory to House Organa, Lieutenant. The ladies will be remanded to the Republic's care as soon as arrangements are made.
I'm glad we could come to an agreement, Pallos.
Sounds good.
Indeed. I apologize in earnest for doubting your commitment to the relationship between our house and the Galactic Republic.
It has to be this way. You have my apologies.
Sorry, Markus.
Yes. I understand.
Great!
You... you're all monsters. Heartless beasts, with no bravery, or--or honor!
We cannot change this, Valyn. Nothing can.
Oh, Markus... my dearest Markus... no....
You'll pay for this. I won't rest until every single one of you has paid for this.
I'm sorry, Valyn. If I could do something else, I would.
I have no choice.
You could've chosen honor. But you didn't.
Bad things happen.
No one's talking to you, little girl.
Quiet!
No, but I'm talking to you. All of you.
You'll pay. Someday, you will. I swear it.
I'll, uh, leave you all to grieve, then. Farewell, Lieutenant, Captain.
Guess you'll move on now, Lieutenant--you got your man, Pallos is happy--everything's tied up.
I really appreciate your assistance, Captain.
Thanks for your help.
Been a pleasure to be part of something so important, sir. A real pleasure.
Just the latest in a career of successful missions.
Another job well-done.
Guess that's what being in Havoc is all about.
Getting away from all this "nobility" sounds great.
I can't wait to leave.
I hear you, friend. I hear you.
I never intended to uphold the bargain I made with Markus, so it doesn't matter.
There is no deal.
No! You wretched, despicable coward!
I should've known not to trust you.
Lieutenant, it seems your services are no longer required. Thank you for your actions on behalf of our house, and good luck in all your future endeavors.
Guess you really wrapped things up here. Had everyone fooled from the beginning.
Havoc Squad doesn't negotiate with the enemy.
All part of the job.
No, I guess you don't.
It's been great working with you, Captain.
Yeah, thanks for your help.
Yeah. You too.
I get the feeling you don't like how I work, Cormac.
You got a problem with me?
Not up to me to tell you your job, sir. Not my place.
See you around, Lieutenant.
Finally have what you came after, eh, Lieutenant? Good luck out there!
I think you'd better take these two on into Markus's cell, Lieutenant.
Oh, uh... uh, hello there, ladies. Welcome to the, uh... detention center.
Where's Markus? You're holding him prisoner in this horrid place, aren't you? I insist that you take me to him at once.
Uh... Lieutenant? What's the call here--you think it's safe to let them in?
I'll take responsibility if anything happens, Captain.
Yes.
We're talking about a prison cell--I think it'll be fine.
Are you kidding?
Heh. Good point, sir, good point.
Let them see how their beloved Markus looks.
It'll be a painful lesson.
All right--take the ladies on in. Cell's open.
Let's move along--I want to bring this nightmarish journey to a close.
Don't be such a crank, mum. Enjoy the adventure! We're going to see father!
Yes, the only thing that brings me comfort in our impending doom. Let's find out what these beasts have done to my Markus.
Be careful, Lieutenant. That Thul compound has a lot of guards. A lot.
So I guess that's it, then. Nothing for it but to rescue the wife and daughter, huh?
At this point, there's no other choice, Captain.
Affirmative.
Well, probably worse things in the galaxy than rescuing noble ladies, even if they are Thuls.
This really isn't what I signed up for.
I can't believe it.
Hey, I know the feeling, Lieutenant. Believe me.
I'm not saving that Imp-lover's family.
Not a chance.
No disrespect, sir, but I really don't know that you have a choice. I've seen how Markus can be--he doesn't talk if he doesn't want to.
I've got you some cloaks here, sir. To disguise the ladies, I mean.
It's going to be tough, getting to those ladies. There's bound to be loads of guards, Imperial and Thul, in every direction.
Thanks for the heads-up, Captain.
I'll stay sharp.
Anytime.
No sweat.
Spare me the commentary.
Uh, sorry. Just trying to help.
Good luck, Lieutenant.
I'll try to keep Pallos in the dark, Lieutenant. But I can't make any promises.
Captain Cormac, I really don't believe I can make myself much clearer than--
Lieutenant! Welcome back, sir! How did your mission go? You know, destroying that giant missile battery that threatened our house, sir?
The battery was destroyed successfully, Captain.
It went well.
Is everything alright, Cormac?
What's going on here?
Oh, of course it is, Lieutenant. Especially knowing that you pulled off such a dangerous mission against Thul and the Imperials.
What, are you kidding?
Well, congratulations! I'd say House Organa really owes you one for taking care of such a dangerous threat.
Ahem, yes, allow me to extend the fondest gratitude of our noble House of Organa for your heroic assistance, Lieutenant.
I am Pallos Thessius Organa, first nephew to his highness, the great duke of Organa. It is an honor to make your acquaintance.
It's good to meet you, too, sir.
Likewise.
Uh, yes, well, indeed.
So you're a real Organa, huh?
First nephew? Nice.
Err, yes, that is quite correct, Lieutenant.
Spare me the ceremonial nonsense--I have work to do.
I don't have time for this.
You'll forgive me my upbringing, I hope. A lifetime of pleasantries leaves its mark.
I am told that you have spent some time in the company of a prisoner, detained herein. One Markus Thul.
This man is of no small consequence to our house, as you may well be aware. What is your interest in him?
Unfortunately, I can't discuss the details of my mission.
I'm afraid that's classified.
Surely you're joking.
Markus has vital intelligence for my operation.
I need his help.
Really, now? Well, House Organa is more than pleased to offer whatever assistance we can to our noble allies in the Galactic Republic.
However, I must ask what you have promised this man in exchange for his vital intelligence. You have promised him something, haven't you?
Ask all you want--but you won't get any answers.
None of your business.
Lieutenant, I'm certain you would agree that my family has a right to know what transpires in our home.
Markus Thul is telling you secrets, which I deeply suspect he would not do without promise of recompense.
As I said, I can't discuss mission details with you.
I can't talk about it.
Begging your pardon, sir, but I really can't discuss mission details.
I can't talk about it.
Your mistrust saddens me. Are we not allies? Can we not confide in one another?
I help him, he helps me--that's how these situations go.
Compromises have to be made.
I see. It is as I suspected, then.
Markus isn't getting anything out of me.
I don't cut deals.
Really, now? You must be a shrewd negotiator indeed.
Well, I'm afraid that house business compels me elsewhere, so I must take my leave of you, Lieutenant.
But let me make something clear: Markus Thul attempted to murder the head of our house. He will not be pardoned for his crime.
Sorry about that. I tried to calm him down, but to Pallos, you're just a stranger, buddying up with the guy who tried to kill his family.
Pallos has a right to seek justice for his family.
I can't blame him.
Yeah, I'd want to put Markus down too, if he came after my family like he did the old duke.
I need Pallos off my back, Cormac--I can't do this without Markus.
Find a way.
Well, I'll try, Lieutenant. But I really don't have much say against people in the family like Pallos.
Nobody interferes with my missions, Cormac. Nobody.
Pallos better stay back.
I gotta say, Lieutenant, it's kind of nice to see someone who doesn't just bow and "yessir" the nobles all day.
I've been watching Markus since you left. Don't think he's made a sound or moved a centimeter.
Still, I'm sure he's been looking forward to your next visit. I'll be out here if you need anything.
Careful out there, Lieutenant! I'll keep watch on Markus, don't worry.
I gotta say, Lieutenant, you're something else. Until you showed up, Markus had barely spouted twenty words at us.
Don't know about this business with Markus's wife and daughter, though. The boys upstairs may not approve of cutting deals with this guy.
Saving the family is the only way to get Markus's intel.
I have no other choice.
Well, then it's probably best if we don't call any attention to ourselves.
Your superiors' opinions have no impact on my mission.
Not my problem.
Okay, sure, but these guys can make life very hard--believe me. Just figured I'd warn you now.
I have no intention of saving Markus's family.
I'm not cutting any deals.
Oh. I... I see. It's all just a trick, then. Makes sense, I guess.
So, what about Markus's story? All of this missile launcher business... you think he's telling the truth?
I don't think he's lying to us.
Yes.
Me neither, actually. I generally don't trust Thuls as a rule, of course, but I get the feeling this guy's too good for lying.
It's hard to say, but there's no choice but to investigate.
Not sure.
Suppose so, sir. Never thought I'd say this about a Thul, but I think I actually believe the guy.
If he is lying, I'll kill him myself.
He'd better be.
You don't mess around, do you?
Well, good luck out there, friend. Who knows--maybe you'll find some clues about this Gearbox guy. I'll keep an eye on Markus while you're gone.
Markus is in holding cell five, Lieutenant. Head right in.
Whoa, hold up a minute, friend. The detention area's restricted. I'm going to need to see some identification before you come in here.
Here you go.
Of course.
Thank you. Let's have a look, then.
You must be Captain Cormac--General Garza sent me.
I'm with the Republic.
Out of the way, grunt.
Oh! I'm sorry, sir, I didn't recognize you. We, uh... well, your general told us someone was coming but didn't say who.
You'll be wanting to talk to our esteemed guest from House Thul, won't you? He's a tough one--we worked him over a dozen times, and he still won't talk.
Your orders were to keep the prisoner in isolation, Captain.
You shouldn't have done that.
I... well, yeah, I mean, we kept him away from all the other prisoners, kept anyone outside from talking to him, sure.
But we... well, I mean, we wanted to be sure the man wasn't wasting your time with some made-up story.
It was good of you to try and help, but this is a Republic matter.
I appreciate it.
General Garza will be informed of what you've done.
I'll have to report this.
I apologize and take full responsibility, Lieutenant, sir. Please tell General Garza that we were only trying to help.
You disobeyed orders. That's all there is to it.
I don't want to hear it.
I apologize, Lieutenant, sir. It absolutely will not happen again.
So, uh, going back to the prisoner, sir. His name is Markus Thul.
I thought he mentioned a man called Gearbox?
What about Gearbox?
Well, yeah, besides that. He mentioned the Gearbox fellow as soon as we brought him in.
How tough can some nobleman be?
So he's a tough guy, huh?
It's unreal. He just stands in there, still and quiet as a stone. Like he doesn't even feel it.
Man's name is Markus Thul. He did tell us that much.
Our boys caught old Markus sneaking into the castle with a dozen Imperial commandos, set on cutting the head of House Organa into thranta bait.
If you captured any Imperials, I'll need to speak with them as well.
Is Markus the only prisoner?
I'm afraid there aren't any, Lieutenant. They all went down during the fight. Took a lot of our boys with 'em, too.
Was anyone in House Organa harmed?
Did you have any casualties?
Nobody in the family was hurt, but a bunch of guards went down in the fighting. It was bad, Lieutenant. Really bad.
Someone must've screwed up big for the Imps to get this close.
Assassins made it here?
I can't speak to that, Lieutenant, but these guys were definitely pros.
Anyways, as soon as we got the shock-cuffs on him, Markus starts in on the Gearbox stuff.
"Critical intelligence, Republic Special Forces will want to know," that sort of thing. That's when we called your people.
I should speak with the prisoner at once.
Let's get to it.
This is all top secret, Captain--don't forget that.
Just remember to keep quiet.
As you say, sir. I wouldn't breath a word of it to anybody.
Let's see if this guy won't spare a few words for me.
I'll make him talk.
Absolutely, sir. Sorry to have held you up so long.
Markus is in holding cell five, Lieutenant. I've set the security door to grant you access, whenever you're ready.
This is the detention area. You need something?
